rationale: All three refer to the same Egyptian burial practice of preserving the dead body, differing only in phrasing; none indicate a distinct concept or variant.
The description clearly describes an action (an act of preserving a corpse) rather than a state, so the type is better modeled as a process.
Refers specifically to the soft organs inside the body removed during mummification, a distinct anatomical concept.
Denotes the particular step of drying a body with salt, a specific sub-process within mummification, not a separate general practice.
Represents the physical material (linen bandages) used in wrapping the body, a distinct material entity from the processes described.
Both mentions refer to the same concept of sacred written documents buried with the deceased to assist them in the afterlife, differing only in wording and type_hint granularity.
All three refer to the same class of ancient Egyptian burial structures, with singular/plural and phrasing variations but identical function and context.
Distinct concept: protective or magical amulets as specific burial objects, not duplicated elsewhere in the group.
Distinct location concept: the specific burial chamber within the tomb, separate from the broader notion of tombs.
The Book of the Dead is a specific, well-defined ancient Egyptian religious text, not duplicated by any other entity here.
Represents the content (collection of spells and prayers) rather than the physical text or scrolls, so it is conceptually distinct from the Book of the Dead entity itself.
Refers specifically to papyrus scrolls as physical writing media, distinct from both the texts and the tomb locations.
Only a single entity is present in the group and it is already specific and coherent as ritual burial objects; no merge or modification is needed.
Refers specifically to the pyramids as a conceptual entry point to the afterlife, distinct from the process or outcome of the soul's journey.
Denotes the spiritual voyage undertaken by the deceased, which is a distinct process concept from both the gateway and the goal state.
Represents the desired successful outcome (safe passage) rather than the gateway or the journey itself, so it should remain a separate goal-state entity.
"Common people in ancient Egypt" and "ordinary Egyptians" are used interchangeably in the same context to describe the same non-elite social group.
"The elite" clearly refers to a distinct high-status social stratum contrasted with common/ordinary Egyptians, so it should remain a separate entity.
All these mentions refer generically to the same concept: the dead person who is the subject of Egyptian burial, mummification, and afterlife beliefs.
This refers specifically to the corpse/body, not a symptom; updating the type to 'Body' better reflects the concept.
Refers to the relatives of the deceased who arrange funerary activities, distinct from the deceased individual and other roles.
Clearly denotes hired professional mourners as a distinct agent role in funerary practices.
Refers to the ceremonial movement of mourners and remains, a specific process distinct from other entities.
Captures the broader set of ritual actions to honor the deceased, which is conceptually distinct from the procession and other agents.

Both mentions describe the same attitude of respectful treatment and commemoration of the dead in ancient Egypt; the difference in wording and type_hint reflects emphasis rather than distinct concepts.
Both mentions share the same name and describe the same ancient Egyptian divine afterlife domain; the differing type hints are compatible and can be unified as a mythological location.
This refers to the desired goal state of unending life among the gods, not the location itself, so it should remain a distinct GoalState entity.
All three entities describe the same belief system about the afterlife in ancient Egypt and are used interchangeably in the same textual context.
This refers specifically to the cultural attitude of reverence toward the deceased, which is related to but distinct from the broader belief system about the afterlife.
All three mentions describe the same Egyptian religious concept of the afterlife; only the type_hint differs slightly, so they should be merged into a single conceptual entity.
Refers specifically to pharaohs, the rulers of ancient Egypt, which is a distinct and clear role.
Clarifies that this entity is distinct from pharaohs and more precisely describes the group as high-status non-royal individuals.
"Burial items" and "grave goods" both denote the same concept of objects interred with the dead for the afterlife, differing only in wording and granularity.
Represents a specific category of offerings (food) within grave goods, not the entire collection, so should remain distinct.
Denotes tools as a specific type of object buried with the deceased, a subset of grave goods rather than the whole concept.
Refers specifically to personal belongings as a subset of objects in burials, conceptually narrower than the merged grave goods entity.
Refers specifically to food items placed in tombs, distinct from clothing, jewelry, or other belongings.
Represents garments buried with the deceased, a different subtype of grave goods from food, jewelry, or miscellaneous items.
Captures jewelry as a specific category of offerings, not identical to food, clothing, or general personal belongings.
Describes other personal objects beyond the explicitly listed categories, so it should remain separate.
Both mentions refer to the same Egyptian concept of a post-death realm, differing only in type label granularity, so they should be represented as one spiritual realm entity.
This refers specifically to the spiritual component of a person (the soul), which is conceptually distinct from the realm of the afterlife and should remain separate.
Represents a specific aspect of burial beliefs (comfort in the afterlife) distinct from sustenance or the general afterlife concept.
Captures a different aspect (provision of nourishment) from comfort and from the broader concept of the afterlife.
Refers to the general concept of the afterlife, not specifically to comfort or sustenance within it, so it should remain separate.
Both mentions refer to the same historical civilization; differences in capitalization and type_hint (Location vs Culture) reflect perspective rather than distinct entities.
This refers specifically to the people of ancient Egypt rather than the civilization or territory itself, so it should remain a distinct entity.
Both mentions refer to the same overall cultural system of ancient Egypt, differing only slightly in phrasing and type_hint but not in conceptual scope.
Egyptian society focuses on social structure and communal life, which is related to but distinct from the broader concept of Egyptian culture, so it should remain a separate entity.
All mentions describe the same ritual and cultural processes around death and burial in ancient Egypt, differing only slightly in wording and scope.
Represents a distinct cultural-mortuary process in ancient Egypt, not duplicated by any other entity in the group.
Denotes a specific religious role (priests) within the burial context, clearly separate from embalmers and other specialists.
Refers specifically to embalmers, a distinct professional role in the burial process, not overlapping with priests or generic specialists.
Captures an intentionally vague collective category of other skilled individuals, distinct from the explicitly named roles.
All three mentions refer to the same concept of large, carefully constructed burial structures in ancient Egyptian burial practices, differing only in phrasing within the same contextual topic.
Refers specifically to the famous pyramid complexes at Giza, a distinct and well-defined location entity.
Refers to pyramids in general as monumental tomb structures, not limited to Giza; broader concept than the specific Giza pyramids.
Refers generically to large pyramid tombs as a class of structures, in contrast to the specific Giza complex; overlap in type but not the same entity.
Refers specifically to the relatives of the deceased; distinct role from hired mourners or the rituals/processes themselves.
Denotes hired specialists performing mourning; distinct from the deceased's family and from the funeral events.
Represents the specific ceremonial movement/event; not an agent and conceptually separate from mourners or family.
Represents the broader set of ritual actions; distinct from the specific procession event and from the people involved.
Both entities describe the same cultural attitude of respect and veneration for the dead in ancient Egypt, differing only in wording and type emphasis.
This refers to the concrete ritual and procedural aspects of ancient Egyptian burial practices, which is related to but distinct from the more abstract value of reverence for the deceased.
Distinct process-level concept describing the overall burial practice in ancient Egypt; no other entity in the group matches this scope.
Refers specifically to priests as a role within burial rites, which is distinct from embalmers and other specialists; no duplicate mention present.
Refers specifically to embalmers as a distinct specialist role in the burial process; not redundant with priests or generic specialists.
Represents a catch-all category of additional unnamed specialists; no other entity captures this generic group.
Both mentions describe the same collective group—people of ancient Egypt involved in the same burial beliefs and practices—differing only in phrasing and type label.
Refers to the broader historical civilization of Ancient Egypt, distinct from its culture, society, or population as separate but related entities.
Clarifying the name to explicitly indicate the culture belongs to ancient Egypt and distinguish it more cleanly from the civilization and society entities.
Renaming to explicitly anchor the society to ancient Egypt and distinguish it from the broader civilization and its culture.
Specifically denotes the non-elite segment of ancient Egyptian society, a subset of the broader population and thus more granular than the merged 'ancient Egyptians' entity.
Refers to the deceased person as an agent in beliefs and practices, not just their physical remains.
Specifically denotes the physical body of the deceased, which is conceptually distinct from the person as a whole.
Both refer to the same Egyptian body-preservation burial practice in this context, with 'body preservation' described specifically as the act within mummification rather than a separate concept.
Refers to anatomical structures (organs) removed during mummification, a distinct concept from the overall process.
Denotes the specific drying-with-salt step, a sub-process within mummification rather than the whole practice.
Represents the material (linen bandages) used in mummification, clearly distinct from the process itself.
Both entries describe the same concept of protective ritual objects included in burials for afterlife protection, differing only slightly in wording and type_hint granularity.
This refers specifically to religious texts buried with the deceased, distinct from physical objects or specific texts like the Book of the Dead.
The burial chamber is a distinct spatial location, not overlapping conceptually with any other entity in the group.
The Book of the Dead is a specific, well-defined ancient Egyptian text, distinct from general religious texts and their physical media.
This denotes the content (spells and prayers) rather than the specific titled work or its physical form, so it remains a separate concept.
Papyrus scrolls are the physical writing medium for texts like the Book of the Dead and are distinct from the texts and amulets themselves.
All three mentions describe the same class of complex burial structures in ancient Egypt, differing only in wording and specificity, with identical function and historical context.
Both refer to high-status non-royal individuals in ancient Egypt who received elaborate tombs, describing the same social group.
Both mention large pyramid tombs in ancient Egypt in a general sense, with 'grand pyramids' being a descriptive variant of the same concept.
Specifically denotes the pyramids at Giza, a particular subset and geographic location distinct from pyramids in general.
Refers specifically to pharaohs, the royal rulers of ancient Egypt, which is distinct from non-royal elites or generic high-status individuals.
Represents the general category of grave goods as a collection, distinct from specific subtypes like food or jewelry offerings.
Refers specifically to food offerings as a component of grave goods, not the entire category.
Refers specifically to clothing offerings as a component of grave goods, distinct from other item types.
Refers specifically to jewelry offerings as a component of grave goods, not a duplicate of other entities.
Covers other personal objects besides food, clothing, and jewelry, a distinct subset within grave goods.
Represents food items in general as grave offerings, distinct from the more explicitly framed 'food offerings' component.
Represents tools as objects buried with the deceased, a distinct object type within the larger grave goods category.
Represents personal belongings as a collection, related to but not identical with 'personal belongings of the deceased' which emphasizes a residual category besides named item types.
Represents a specific aspect (comfort) of the deceased's post-death state; distinct from sustenance and from the broader concept of the afterlife.
Represents a separate aspect (sustenance/nourishment) of the deceased's post-death state; not identical to comfort or to the general afterlife concept.
Denotes the general concept of the afterlife itself, which is broader and ontologically different from specific conditions like comfort or sustenance within it.
Refers to a mythological location (the divine afterlife domain itself), distinct from any state or condition related to it.
Represents a goal state (ongoing life among the gods) rather than the location itself, so it should not be merged with the mythological place.
Refers specifically to the conceptual role of pyramids as an entry point to the afterlife, distinct from the process or goal of the journey itself.
Denotes the spiritual process or voyage after death, which is conceptually different from both the gateway structure and the desired outcome of safe arrival.
Represents the desired successful outcome (goal state) of the journey, not the journey process or the gateway mechanism, so it should remain distinct.

Both entities describe the same ancient Egyptian religious concept of the afterlife; the difference is only in labeling (Concept vs BeliefSystem), and they are explicitly said to be interchangeable in context.
Represents the Egyptian post-death realm itself, a distinct spiritual location/concept separate from the soul.
Represents the spiritual component of a person, which is conceptually distinct from the afterlife realm it inhabits.
Refers specifically to the relatives of the deceased, distinct from mourners, processions, or rituals.

Represents the ceremonial movement (process) during a funeral, not an agent or general ritual, so should remain separate.

Represents the population (people) of ancient Egypt, which is conceptually distinct from the civilization as a polity and its culture as an abstract system.

Internal organs are a separate anatomical concept from the process of mummification and are described specifically as the body parts removed during the procedure.

Linen bandages are a specific material used in the process and represent a separate, concrete entity from the procedures and anatomical structures.
Represents the general class of ancient Egyptian tomb structures (including but not limited to pyramids), which is broader than the other, more specific entities.

Denotes the specific, famous pyramid complexes at Giza, which are a particular instance/location subset of Egyptian pyramids, not the same as the general class.
Refers to the human rulers (pharaohs) for whom such tombs were built, a distinct role/entity type unrelated to the structural entities.
Refers specifically to the elite, high-status non-royal social stratum in ancient Egypt, distinct from the general population or the civilization as a whole.
Denotes the entire population of ancient Egyptians, a broader group than either the elite or non-elite subgroups and conceptually distinct from the civilization/culture entities.
